conclusion: We have a conducting rod OC that rotates with angular velocity ω around point O.
The rod slides along a semi-circular conducting frame of radius r.
There's a uniform magnetic field with intensity B (perpendicular to the plane based on the X marks in the figure).
A resistor R is connected between points O and C.
The resistances of the frame and rod are negligible.

premise: When the rod OC rotates in the magnetic field, it cuts through magnetic field lines, which induces an EMF.
conclusion: The rate of change of magnetic flux can be calculated by considering the area swept by the rod per unit time.

premise: At any instant, if the rod makes an angle θ with the horizontal, its length is r.
conclusion: As it rotates, the instantaneous rate of change of area is: \( \frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{1}{2}r^2\omega \).
This gives us the induced EMF: \( \mathcal{E} = B\frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{1}{2}Br^2\omega \).
The current in the circuit is \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} = \frac{Br^2\omega}{2R} \).
The magnetic force on the rod is \( F_B = BIL = BI \cdot r \).

premise: Substituting the current \( I = \frac{Br^2\omega}{2R} \) into \( F_B = BI \cdot r \).
conclusion: The magnetic force is \( F_B = B \cdot \frac{Br^2\omega}{2R} \cdot r = \frac{B^2r^3\omega}{2R} \).

premise: For the rod to move at constant angular velocity, an external force must be applied to overcome the magnetic force.
conclusion: This external force must be equal in magnitude to the magnetic force but opposite in direction.
The power of the external force is \( P = F \cdot v = F_B \cdot (r\omega) = \frac{B^2r^3\omega}{2R} \cdot r\omega \).
